text: <@U027PV4AP> It says you can’t rollover your Simple IRA unless you’ve had it for four years. So what happens if you don’t roll it over? Does it just sit there in my fidelity account until I’m old enough to access it?

Also, it sounds to me like a pre-tax contribution doesn’t tax it as it goes in but taxes it as it comes out of your account later. Whereas a roth contribution taxes on the way in but not on the way out… which is better, from a financial standpoint?

On your second question, It's good to have both a pre-tax and a post-tax retirement account if you aren't certain either way. Good info here: <http://www.forbes.com/sites/financialfinesse/2012/09/12/why-the-pre-tax-v-roth-decision-is-more-complex-than-it-seems/#790a5a752c91>

<@U051P3FPY> an old colleague recommended this book to me when I was in my early 20s and it was extremely informative if you can get past her cheeseball writing <https://www.amazon.com/Money-Book-Young-Fabulous-Broke/dp/1594482241>
added that to my list too, thanks <@U0260V1BX> :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U051P3FPY>: great questions! unfortunately i and uncorked cannot advise you on how you should invest your money since we are not advisors. the best thing to do is to call guideline and have them explain the nuances then you can make an educated decision.
as for your simple. yes it will sit in your account with fidelity until you can move that money.
i'm happy to chat more when back next week!
Roth is post tax. 401k is pretax. So if you think your marginal tax rate upon retirement will be higher than it is now, Roth is better

<@U051P3FPY> I've rolled over a Simple IRA from a previous job (also with Fidelity). When the holding period is up, I believe they'll send you an email with next steps. (Calling Fidelity or going into their office downtown is a good option, they have people who can help.) In my case, I rolled over my Simple into a SEP IRA, which is another type of traditional (pre-tax contribution) IRA for self-employed people. You can also convert rollover assets to a Roth IRA, but a tax bill comes with that conversion.
<@U02F8TTPU> I would love to hear Brian's talk again since I missed it!
Oh god, Suze Orman...
<@U0J6TE0CA> I showed him a bit of our conversation thread on Fri night, he's interested in giving it again :slightly_smiling_face: Will chat about it at events chat this week!
<@U027PV4AP> <@U2DTF0B6Y> i havent received an email from guideline - is there any way to check in on this? (unless i am just jumping the gun)
We'll look into it! Can you double check your spam folder?
checked (both personal + work) - no dice - appreciate you looking into!
thanks for checking. we'll get back to you ASAP!

I’m a bit confused, <@U027PV4AP> could you clarify <@U051P3FPY>’s question about IRAs rolling over after 4 years as opposed to the 2 years you mentioned? Not sure where to find the literature for either of these positions.
Sorry, I think I meant 2 years
Oh! ok cool. Thanks Kaitlyn
<@U026E0ZNR>: <@U051P3FPY> with the simple it's a two year waiting period. meaning you must have had your simple ira for at least two years.
So after the 2 years are up, then I can roll it over into whatever I have?
yes.
:thanks:
_retirement is harrrrrrd_
we can look next week to find out how much longer your wait is. i'm OOO this week.
i have two questions: 1) how much does UC match? 2) what fees will we be paying?
(for 2 i am trying to compare with another 401k i have to determine whether i should roll over into this new one)
The match is 4% I believe
<@U2DTF0B6Y> ^
It is 4% (according to the guideline setup).
nice thx!

<@U167FL70V> the fee question is a good one, and i can’t be sure I’m answering the whole question honestly since I’m more the client of Stephanie’s research than the informed party… but we pay $8/user/month instead of the normal % fee model. pretty exciting difference from the types that bleed the pool (which fights the gains).

we have kept a critical eye on making sure the benefit actually benefits, cause a lot of employers have the option to pull some or all of the costs of having the program onto the employees. our goal was to wait until we could afford to shoulder the cost of the program, and keep the costs on ourselves. there is some tiny unavoidable fee somewhere, and all i can remember about it is that it seemed reasonable and probably unavoidable for Guideline.
oh interesting!
WOAH!

yeah!! so excited. There are quite a few 401k management companies who "specialize" in small businesses... providing a limited menu of funds with high expense ratios, confusing user interfaces and making it easy to invest in things that for various reasons may not be best for the individual

(been there done that in startupland... and then there are the companies that feed off of employees of BigCos, providing incentives to sink unbalanced amounts of retirement $$ into their own companies, i.e. MCI, Enron, Compaq...)
